articles.headline: Germany’s Siemens Says Russian Partner Violated Crimea Sanctions
articles.snippet: The incident threatens to strain relations between the two countries and demonstrates how energy has become a weapon in Russia’s struggle with Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The incident threatens to strain relations between the two countries and demonstrates how energy has become a weapon in Russia’s struggle with Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — One of Germany’s biggest companies said Monday that it had become an unwitting pawn in a scheme to evade sanctions against Russia and break a de facto blockade of electricity to the annexed territory Crimea.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: U.S. Agency Moves to Allow Class-Action Lawsuits Against Financial Firms
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is adopting a rule that would block banks and credit card companies from forcing customers into arbitration.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is adopting a rule that would block banks and credit card companies from forcing customers into arbitration.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s consumer watchdog adopted a rule on Monday that would pry open the courtroom doors for millions of Americans, by prohibiting financial firms from forcing them into arbitration in disputes over their bank and credit card accounts.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Iraq Celebrates Victory Over ISIS in Mosul, but Risks Remain
articles.snippet: As the battle with the Islamic State in Mosul nears an end, other conflicts on the margins are flaring and a threat to the Iraqi state and society remains.
articles.abstract: As the battle with the Islamic State in Mosul nears an end, other conflicts on the margins are flaring and a threat to the Iraqi state and society remains.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq — The fighting is all but over in Mosul, and the billboards are already up: hastily raised signs in which the government urged the city’s Sunni residents to “turn the page” from the terrorists of the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Foes of Obama-Era Rule Work to Undo Birth Control Mandate
articles.snippet: A lawyer and an epidemiologist who fought against the Affordable Care Act’s rule on contraception coverage from the outside are now the architects of the president’s reversal.
articles.abstract: A lawyer and an epidemiologist who fought against the Affordable Care Act’s rule on contraception coverage from the outside are now the architects of the president’s reversal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the obscure perch of a backbench senator’s office, Katy Talento used to warn against what she saw as the health hazards of birth control pills — cancer, infertility and miscarriage. From his post at a Christian legal advocacy group, Matthew Bowman spent years attacking the requirement that most health insurance plans cover contraception under the Affordable Care Act.

articles.headline: E-Commerce as a Jobs Engine? One Economist’s Unorthodox View
articles.snippet: The common refrain is that Amazon and other e-tailers are killing retail jobs, but one new statistical analysis begs to differ.
articles.abstract: The common refrain is that Amazon and other e-tailers are killing retail jobs, but one new statistical analysis begs to differ.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retailing is dead. Sales clerks are losing their jobs by the thousands. The employment picture for young people with only a high school education is going to get even worse. And all this is happening because of Amazon and its ilk, which are driving the shift among consumers toward e-commerce.

articles.headline: Trump Jr. Was Told in Email of Russian Effort to Aid Campaign
articles.snippet: The president’s son was told in an email that the Russian government wanted to help Donald J. Trump’s election bid last year.
articles.abstract: The president’s son was told in an email that the Russian government wanted to help Donald J. Trump’s election bid last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times now has the email to Donald Trump Jr. offering Russian aid to “incriminate Hillary.” His reply: “If it’s what you say I love it.” Read the new article.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Jo Becker, Adam Goldman and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump Aides Recruited Businessmen to Devise Options for Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A founder of a private security firm and an owner of a military contractor have discussed proposals to rely more on contractors instead of American troops.
articles.abstract: A founder of a private security firm and an owner of a military contractor have discussed proposals to rely more on contractors instead of American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s advisers recruited two businessmen who profited from military contracting to devise alternatives to the Pentagon’s plan to send thousands of additional troops to Afghanistan, reflecting the Trump administration’s struggle to define its strategy for dealing with a war now 16 years old.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Eric Schmitt and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: The Deep Industry Ties of Trump’s Deregulation Teams
articles.snippet: A campaign to cut government rules is being conducted largely out of public view, often by hires with potential conflicts, an investigation has found.
articles.abstract: A campaign to cut government rules is being conducted largely out of public view, often by hires with potential conflicts, an investigation has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump entered office pledging to cut red tape, and within weeks, he ordered his administration to assemble teams to aggressively scale back government regulations.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Robert Faturechi

articles.headline: North Koreans in Russia Work ‘Basically in the Situation of Slaves’
articles.snippet: North Korea, desperate for foreign currency, has sent tens of thousands of its citizens to Russia, where they are welcomed as “fast, cheap and reliable” laborers.
articles.abstract: North Korea, desperate for foreign currency, has sent tens of thousands of its citizens to Russia, where they are welcomed as “fast, cheap and reliable” laborers.
articles.lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — Across Western Europe and the United States, immigrants from poorer countries, whether plumbers from Poland or farmhands from Mexico, have become a lightning rod for economic anxieties over cheap labor.

articles.headline: Is a More Prosperous World More Secure? Not as Trump Sees It
articles.snippet: The president has abandoned a policy consensus that alleviating poverty around the world is a key to reducing the chances of instability and conflict.
articles.abstract: The president has abandoned a policy consensus that alleviating poverty around the world is a key to reducing the chances of instability and conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the end of World War II, American foreign policy has understood the role of economic development in the prevention of conflict around the world — providing a subtle yet powerful contribution to the United States’ own national security.

articles.headline: Russian Dirt on Clinton? ‘I Love It,’ Donald Trump Jr. Said
articles.snippet: Email exchanges reviewed by The Times offer a detailed unspooling of how an eager Donald Trump Jr. came to meet with a Kremlin-connected lawyer.
articles.abstract: Email exchanges reviewed by The Times offer a detailed unspooling of how an eager Donald Trump Jr. came to meet with a Kremlin-connected lawyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The June 3, 2016, email sent to Donald Trump Jr. could hardly have been more explicit: One of his father’s former Russian business partners had been contacted by a senior Russian government official and was offering to provide the Trump campaign with dirt on Hillary Clinton.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker, Adam Goldman and Matt Apuzzo
